title: How to Increase Your Vertical Leap

steps.title: Do plyometric exercises to build up your leg muscles.
steps.content: Do plyometric exercises to build up your leg muscles. Plyometric exercises are one of the best ways to improve your vertical leap. These exercises use explosive force to train and build your muscles. These exercises all incorporate jumping and rely on your body weight to achieve results. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Limit your plyometric workouts to twice a week with at least two days of rest between workouts. Give yourself at least one full rest day per week.

steps.title: Perform jump squats.
steps.content: Perform jump squats. [2] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. Place your feet hip-width apart, and squat as low as you can. Instead of rising back up slowly, though, jump from squatting position and try to turn 180 degrees. Come down from the jump in another squat––don't try to land standing straight up. Repeat, changing directions when you jump. For instance, turn to the right the first time, then turn to the left, and so on. [3] X Research source Do 3 sets of 5 until it feels easy, then increase to 3 sets of 8.

steps.title: Do Bulgarian split squats.
steps.content: Do Bulgarian split squats. Stand a few steps away from a bench or chair, and place your non-working leg up on the seat with the top of your foot flat on the seat of the chair. Lower your body until your back knee is nearly touching the floor, then push back up through the heel of your front foot that is on the floor. This is one rep. [4] X Research source Do 3 sets of 8 reps.

steps.title: Perform box jumps.
steps.content: Perform box jumps. [5] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. Get a sturdy box or platform that will hold your weight. Place the box in front of you. Explosively jump up onto the box or platform. Use as much power as possible. Jump back down and land in a crouching position. Start with 3 reps. Focus on intensity rather than quantity.

steps.title: Jump rope.
steps.content: Jump rope. Jumping rope strengthens the muscles you need to execute a vertical leap and helps improve your jumping abilities. Jump on a firm surface, such as hardwood floor, where there’ll be plenty of room over your head for the rope. Jump for ten minutes per day. If you can’t do it all at once, you can break it up into two to three minute jumping segments, broken up by resting periods and/or other exercises. [6] X Research source Don't "skip" rope, where you essentially jump with one foot in a sort of running-in-place motion. Instead, try to keep your ankles together as you jump with both feet at the same time. As you improve, jump faster. You might start out moving the rope slowly, taking a small hop between jumps to maintain your balance. When you're ready, move the rope more quickly and get rid of the balance hop.

steps.title: Perform calisthenics every day to increase flexibility.
steps.content: Perform calisthenics every day to increase flexibility. Calisthenics includes basic bodyweight exercises that help build up your muscles. Because you don’t need any equipment, you can do calisthenics anywhere to build strength and agility. To improve your vertical leap, do calisthenics that target your leg muscles. Some examples of calisthenics include push-ups, jumping jacks, sit-ups, and lunges.

steps.title: Stretch
steps.content: Stretch daily. Not only will stretching help protect your body during the rest of your workout, it will also improve your jumping abilities by loosening your muscles.

steps.title: Perform calf raises.
steps.content: Perform calf raises . Stand with your legs together. Lift yourself onto your toes, then lower yourself down. Move slowly to make the muscles work harder. [7] X Research source For better results, stand on the edge of a curb or a step. Start with 20 reps, increasing as the move gets easier.

steps.title: Do deep squats.
steps.content: Do deep squats. Place your feet hip-width apart, and keep your heels flat on the ground. Slowly lower yourself as far as you can by simply bending your knees while keeping your back erect and your neck straight. Lift back up to starting position. [8] X Research source Your thighs should go below your knee when doing a deep squat. A good squat should feel like it's working the entire lower half of your body, as well as stretching the core muscles around your back and abdomen. Start out with 3 sets of 10 squats. Do some squats while keeping your weight on your tiptoes. This will help you strengthen your ankles.

steps.title: Do lunges
steps.content: Do lunges . [9] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Fitness Coach Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. Start in a standing position. Take a big step forward, bending your front knee. Lean your body forward with your front knee lined up vertically above your ankle. Rise back to a standing position. Alternate your legs. Do 3 sets with 10 reps on each side.

steps.title: Stand on one leg.
steps.content: Stand on one leg. Alternate standing on each of your legs so that your ankles become stronger. This may help to prevent you from getting an ankle injury when you land your jumps. Stand up straight and focus on an object straight ahead of you. Bring one foot off of the ground and hold this position until your leg starts to get tired. Then switch your weight to the other leg and repeat this process.

steps.title: Do weight training to build up the strength of your leg muscles.
steps.content: Do weight training to build up the strength of your leg muscles. Strengthening your leg muscles can improve your jumping abilities. Weight exercises that target your leg muscles will help you improve your vertical leap. Do weight training two to three times per week.

steps.title: Do trap bar deadlifts.
steps.content: Do trap bar deadlifts. Trap bars are different from regular barbells because they have an open center that allows the user to step inside. You will stand inside the center of the barbell. Bend down, grasp the barbell, and stand up. Lift the trap bar as you rise, keeping the barbell close your body as you rise. Keep your arms at your sides. Hold the weight for a moment, then lower it. Your deadlift weights should be as heavy as you can lift. Keep the bar close to your body and your arms extended down. Don’t lock your elbows.

steps.title: Try single-arm dumbbell snatches.
steps.content: Try single-arm dumbbell snatches. Place a dumbbell down on the floor in front of you. Squat down and grasp the dumbbell with one hand. Stand up, lifting the dumbbell as you rise. Extend your dumbbell above your head. Hold, then lower the weight back to the starting position. Do 3 sets of 8 reps. Start with a low weight and focus on your speed.

steps.title: Do weighted squats.
steps.content: Do weighted squats. Place your feet hip-width apart. Lift a barbell or two dumbbells up to your shoulders and rest them on your shoulders. Lower yourself as far down as you can, maintaining the weights in position. Rise back into standing position. [10] X Research source Do 3 sets of 8. If using dumbbells, start with 5-lb (2.25 kg) weights, then progress to 7- (3 kg) to 8-lb (3.5 kg) weights. If using a barbell, start with just the bar.

steps.title: Practice your jump.
steps.content: Practice your jump. Every few days, try a few vertical leaps to track your progress. Don't focus on vertical leaps as your primary means of training, though; doing them over and over will result in slower progression than doing targeted exercises to prime your body for athletic performance. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Measure your current vertical leap.
steps.content: Measure your current vertical leap. Stand near a tall wall or pole and raise your hand as far as you can. Have a friend measure where your hand reaches up to (make a mark with chalk or a similar marking tool). Then jump with that same hand raised, and have your friend try to measure where your fingertips hit the wall. Subtract your original measurement from your jump measurement. This is your current vertical leap. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Choose a way to track your increases.
steps.content: Choose a way to track your increases. You'll need to keep track of your measurements and when they were taken. Write the date you took the measurements and how high you jumped. There are several options for tracking your measurements, depending on your preferences. You could use paper, your computer, or your phone. Keep it simple by writing down your numbers. Type your numbers into a document or spreadsheet if you prefer to use the computer. Keep track of the numbers on your phone in the notes app or a word processing app.

steps.title: Take new measurements weekly.
steps.content: Take new measurements weekly. How often you measure your vertical leap is up to you, but measuring weekly will provide consistency and allow time for improvements between measurements. If you forget to measure on your normal day, measure the next time you get a chance.
